column1: In Weyerhaeuser Company v. US Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS), will the Supreme Court rule that the FWS erroneously applied the Endangered Species Act (ESA) to any private land in St. Tammany Parish, Louisiana?
column6: ['US Policy']
SCOTUS will tell the froggies that "no residency" gives them "no rights."

With the recent ideological make-up of the Supreme Court, a case such as this one that seems to hold St. Tammany Parish in the right, it's extremely likely that the Court will determine this case in favor of the Weyerhaeuser Company.
Any government regulation of this sort is "government overreach" to conservatives, including those on the court, these days, even though that's an arrant absurdity.

It's likely the Court will rule in favor of the corporate interest in this case. Recent rulings around EPA and environmental issues would seem to support this. Besides, as stated, the case might seem clear. Republicans would call it "regulatory overreach."
With a Right leaning court, prevailing wisdom is they will restrict Govt. over reach.
Given the multiple rulings in favor of the FWS it would be unlikely that SCOTUS would decide against them.

The first case, Weyerhaeuser Company v. United States Fish and Wildlife Service concerns the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's (FWS) designation of private land in Louisiana as critical habitat for the dusky gopher frog. Under the Endangered Species Act, property owners of critical habitat are barred from most uses of the property. In this case, the FWS designation requires the property owners to uproot trees and replace them with different species; halt timber management activities; and allow the land to be populated with frogs. The Fifth Circuit affirmed the district court's ruling that deferred to the FWS habitat designation. The Supreme Court's decision could turn on the degree of deference afforded the FWS, and what constitutes agency discretion.

If you don't refer to scotusblog.com and are a legal layman, you have little chance to forecast our Supreme Court decisions accurately. The link below is to a podcast about this case. Richard A. Epstein of NYU is a guest. He's brilliant! I very much agree with his opinions about the proper approach to interpret law. In this case Epstein thinks that the Court is tasked with answering the wrong question. Anyway, I think the correct answer is 'yes," and that it is likely that the Court will get it right. However, there is a chance that the split (without Kavanaugh) will be 4-4, so 15% chance wrong decision or no decision this term
corruption in the system will have to be stopped
Test 10. This is difficult. Government should have tried to make a better case. I think the Court may not decide this case before deadline. Rehear arguments with Kavanaug? Delay!
It would be a taking if they don't.
Boy, this is a tough one.

My prediction is not based on what I believe, but on what I think the Justices believe, by reading their line of questions in the oral argument. While the Court seems to be divided along the natural fault line, the questions and answers aren't easy to read, since there are many interruptions. But in the end, I believe the Court, will side with Weyerhaeuser, especially when later, Judge Kavanaugh will be confirmed and join the Court. I could even see Justice Breyer concur with the majority, but writing his own opinion. (EDIT: but perhaps he could use what the government lawyer suggested to him, that since the conservation is in line with current usage, the designation of "critical habitat" isn't outlandish. In that case, he will side with the liberal Justices).
I would like to encourage people to submit reasons for their view on this case.

Oral argument suggests no defection by the Chief should this end up ideological. Worst case for Weyerhaeuser, it's 4-4, they reargue in the Spring when there's nine (most likely), and we can reexamine.
They will say that the land has to be an actual habitat of the animal.
Cases take a long time and while justice system is out to lunch
Interesting case.
They will rule for the corporation because the critical habitat argument is flawed
The Ruling will 6-3., Because ruling private land that doesn't have the frog or the habitat as critical is a "Taking"
Neither the current nor any likely Supreme Court in the near future will approve of any restrictions on any private property, even if it is carpeted in dusky gopher frogs.

Since the land in question is both private and is the product of replanted trees, meaning most trees harvested are like crops. and harvested at maturity and then replanted for cutting in 10 years, The federal government can not show that this frog is part of or a critical habitat due to the rate of harvest.
